In title fights, the participants must weight no more than that permitted for the relevant weight division. The Commission may also approve catch weight bouts, subject to their review and discretion. For example, the Commission may still decide to allow the contest the maximum weight allowed is 177 pounds if it feels that the contest would still be fair, safe, and competitive. In addition, there are five weight classes specified in the Unified Rules which the UFC does not currently use: Super Lightweight (165 pounds), Super Welterweight (175 pounds), Super Middleweight (195 pounds), Cruiserweight (225 pounds), and Super Heavyweight (>265 pounds). == Current UFC pound-for-pound ranking == {| class="wikitable" |1 |Daniel Cormier |- |2 |Khabib Nurmagomedov |- |3 |Jon Jones |- |4 |T.J. Dillashaw |- |5 |Max Holloway |- |6 |Georges St-Pierre |- |7 |Tyron Woodley |- |8 |Conor McGregor |- |9 |Stipe Miocic |- |9 |Henry Cejudo |- |11 |Cris Cyborg |- |12 |Robert Whittaker |- |13 |Tony Ferguson |- |14 |Amanda Nunes |- |15 |Rose Namajunas |} ==UFC events== {{Main|List of UFC events}} MMA journalists and fans have criticized the UFC for putting on too many shows and thus diluting the quality of their product.{{refn|Criticism for number of shows{{cite news|title=UFC Aftermath: Trying to Understand the "Angry Watching" Phenomenon|url=http://theprovince.com/sports/mma/ufc-aftermath-trying-to-understand-the-angry-watching-phenomenon|accessdate=October 31, 2016|work=[[The Province]]|date=April 14, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Iole|first1=Kevin|title=Dana White says business is booming, will have $175 million economic impact in Las Vegas this week|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/mma-cagewriter/dana-white-says-ufc-business-is-booming--will-have--175-million-economic-impact-in-las-vegas-181005876.html|accessdate=October 31, 2016|publisher=[[Yahoo! Sports]]}}{{cite web|title=Live Chat: UFC Fight Night weekend preview, GLORY 17 recap, over saturation debate|url=https://youtube.com/watch?v=roWwSOSQ9Ps|website=[[YouTube]] (MMAFighting.com official channel)|accessdate=October 31, 2016|date=June 25, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Raimondi|first1=Marc|title=ONE CEO: Goal is to put on 50 shows per year|url=http://www.mmafighting.com/2015/3/11/8181445/one-championship-ceo-goal-is-to-put-on-50-shows-per-year|work=MMA Fighting|publisher=[[SB Nation]] (MMAFighting.com)|date=March 11, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Schlinsky|first1=Alex|title=UFC 180 Details: Who is Fighting, When And Why|url=http://www.mmamania.com/2014/11/15/7219929/ufc-180-start-time-schedule-fighting-tonight-when-why-mexico-city-mma-ppv|accessdate=October 31, 2016|work=[[SB Nation]] (MMAmania.com)|date=November 15, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Wyman|first1=Patrick|title=How the UFC Has Done More with Less in 2015|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2563685-how-the-ufc-has-done-more-with-less-in-2015|accessdate=October 31, 2016|work=[[Bleacher Report]]}}{{cite news|title=UFC's Oversaturation and Overcommitment Problems|url=http://mmanuts.com/news/ufcs-oversaturation-overcommitment-problems/|accessdate=October 31, 2016|work=www.mmanuts.com|date=April 20, 2014}}{{cite news|title=MMA: Are too many shows watering down the sport?|url=http://fansided.com/2014/07/17/mma-many-shows-watering-sport/|accessdate=October 31, 2016|work=www.FanSided.com|date=July 17, 2014}}}} ===Production team=== [[File:AriannyLopez.png|thumb|230px|Octagon girl [[Arianny Celeste]]]] Comedian, Brazilian jiu-jitsu and Taekwondo black belt[http://www.answers.com/topic/joe-rogan Joe Rogan: Information from]. Answers.com. Retrieved on May 3, 2011. [[Joe Rogan]] teams up with [[Sports commentator|play-by-play]] announcer [[Jon Anik]] to provide commentary during broadcasts of most UFC events in the US. For 20 years{{refn|1997-2016}} Joe Rogan and [[Mike Goldberg]] provided commentary at live events.1997: {{Hanging indent | {{cite news|last=Reynolds |first=Robert |url=http://mmadiehards.com/live/features/ufc-announcer-mike-goldberg-goes-from-pucks-to-punchouts/|title=UFC announcer Mike Goldberg goes from pucks to punchouts |publisher=MMADieHards.com}}}} 2016: {{Hanging indent | {{cite web|title=UFC commentator Mike Goldberg leaving the promotion following UFC 207|url=http://www.mmafighting.com/2016/12/28/14106184/ufc-commentator-mike-goldberg-leaving-the-promotion-following-ufc-207|website=MMAFighting|accessdate=December 29, 2016}}}} The "Veteran Voice of the Octagon" is announcer [[Bruce Buffer]].{{cite news|author = Hackler, Tracy|title = MMA's Bruce Buffer Makes a Name for Himself|publisher = ESPN Page 2|date = August 27, 2010|url = http://www.xyience.com/index.cfm?fa=news.detail&gid=255&newsCategoryId=46|accessdate = September 16, 2010|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110407174453/http://www.xyience.com/index.cfm?fa=news.detail&gid=255&newsCategoryId=46|archivedate = April 7, 2011|df = mdy-all}} [[Arianny Celeste]], Rachelle Leah, Brittney Palmer, Carly Baker, Vanessa Hanson, Chrissy Blair, Jhenny Andrade, Camila Oliveira, Luciana Andrade, Jamilette Gaxiola, and Red Dela Cruz are [[ring girl|Octagon girls]].[http://www.ufc.com/octagonGirl UFC Octagon Girls] UFC.com Retrieved September 16, 2010. Each fighter is assigned a [[cutman]] by the promotion who cares for the fighter before the fight and in between rounds. [[Jacob Duran|Jacob "Stitch" Duran]] was one of the best known cutmen working for the organization.{{cite news|author = Borges, Ron|title = Cutman has made mark|publisher = [[Boston Herald]]|date = August 29, 2010|url = http://www.bostonherald.com/sports/other_sports/ultimate_fighting/view.bg?articleid=1277704|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100901141416/http://www.bostonherald.com/sports/other_sports/ultimate_fighting/view.bg?articleid=1277704|dead-url = yes|archive-date = September 1, 2010|accessdate = September 16, 2010}} Matches are made by matchmakers, and VP of Talent Relations, Joe Silva and Sean Shelby.{{cite news|author = Kid Nate|title = How the UFC Books Fights|publisher = Bloodyelbow.com|date = September 3, 2010|url = http://www.bloodyelbow.com/2010/9/3/1667816/how-the-ufc-books-fights|accessdate = September 16, 2010}} ===Fighter salaries and contracts=== UFC fighters are paid per fight, with amounts depending on how well-known the fighters are and how well sponsored a fighter and an event is. Fighters will typically get paid money to fight, called show money, with an additional bonus if they win, called a win bonus. While fighters new to the UFC can make as little as about $10,000 per fight (without a win bonus), more established fighters have made as much as $500,000 to $1 million per fight. Occasionally, fighters will earn more. For example, at [[UFC 202]], [[Conor McGregor]] made a reported $3 million, a UFC record for one fight, while his opponent [[Nate Diaz]] made a reported $2 million. The combined $5 million made between the fighters was the largest combined fight purse in UFC history.{{cite web |title=Conor McGregor Breaks Brock Lesnar's Record for Biggest Fight Purse at UFC 202 |url=https://bleacherreport.com/articles/2658946-conor-mcgregor-breaks-brock-lesnars-record-for-biggest-fight-purse-at-ufc-202 |website=BleacherReport.com}} Cash bonuses are also awarded for "Fight of the Night" and "Performance of the Night" (formerly awarded separately as "Knockout of the Night").{{cite web|url=http://mmanuts.com/news/ufc-eliminates-ko-submission-night-awards/|title=UFC Eliminates KO and Submission of the Night Awards |publisher=mmanuts.com|author=Dave Walsh |date=February 11, 2014|accessdate= February 11, 2014}} The size of these bonuses can sometimes be $80,000 USD (but are normally $50,000 USD). For less well-known fighters, they can be several times larger than the contracted amount for the fight.{{cite web|title=UFC Post-Fight Bonuses Now Set at $15,000 for Every Event|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/ufc-post-fight-bonuses-now-030421521--mma.html|publisher=MMA Weekly|accessdate=April 13, 2013|date=March 14, 2013}} Contracted amounts generally have to be declared to the state athletic commission; however, the UFC also pays undisclosed locker-room bonuses to fighters.{{cite web |url=http://mmajunkie.com/news/15498/ufc-100-fighters-salaries-brock-lesnar-and-georges-st-pierre-top-earners-from-x-x-million-payroll.mma |title=UFC 100 fighters salaries: Lesnar and St. Pierre get top paydays in $1.8 million payroll |publisher=MMAjunkie.com |accessdate=July 13, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090715131951/http://mmajunkie.com/news/15498/ufc-100-fighters-salaries-brock-lesnar-and-georges-st-pierre-top-earners-from-x-x-million-payroll.mma |archivedate=July 15, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} In recent years, UFC fighters' contracts and merchandising rights have been the subject of dispute between fighters (represented by growing the Mixed Martial Arts Fighters Association) and UFC, which has attempted to defend existing regulations.{{cite news|url=http://www.tnr.com/article/politics/magazine/103397/ufc-mma-labor-unions-carrano-white-gsp-bill-culinary |title=No Holds Barred: Labor turmoil in the world of mixed martial arts. |accessdate=May 30, 2012 |date=May 30, 2012 |first=Jesse |last=Zwick |work=The New Republic}} ==UFC records== {{main|List of UFC records}} {| class="wikitable" |- !Record!!Fighter!!Number |- |Youngest Champion|| [[Jon Jones]]||23 years, 8 months |- |Oldest Champion|| [[Randy Couture]]||45 years, 146 days |- |Longest reign as a Champion|| [[Anderson Silva]]||2,457d (6y 8m 22d) |- |Most championship reigns|| [[Anderson Silva]]||10 |- |Most Bouts|| [[Jim Miller (fighter)|Jim Miller]] ||30 |- |Most Wins||[[Donald Cerrone]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.mmafighting.com/2018/11/11/18083962/ufc-denver-results-donald-cerrone-sets-ufc-records-with-win-over-mike-perry|title=UFC Denver results: Donald Cerrone sets UFC records with win over Mike Perry|work=MMA Fighting|access-date=2018-11-11}}||21 |- |Most Finishes||[[Donald Cerrone]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.mmafighting.com/2018/11/11/18083962/ufc-denver-results-donald-cerrone-sets-ufc-records-with-win-over-mike-perry|title=UFC Denver results: Donald Cerrone sets UFC records with win over Mike Perry|work=MMA Fighting|access-date=2018-11-11}}||15 |- |Most Knockouts|| [[Vitor Belfort]]||12 |- |Most Submissions|| [[Charles Oliveira]]||11 |- |Most Decision Wins|| [[Georges St-Pierre]]||12 |- |Most wins in title bouts|| [[Georges St-Pierre]]||13 |- |Most title bouts|| [[Randy Couture]]
[[Georges St-Pierre]]||15 |- |Most consecutive title defenses|| [[Demetrious Johnson (fighter)|Demetrious Johnson]]||11 |- |Longest winning streak|| Anderson Silva||16 |- |Most Post Fight Awards|| [[Nate Diaz]]
[[Joe Lauzon]]||15 |- |Most Performance of the Night Awards|| [[Conor McGregor]]
[[Charles Oliveira]]||6 |- |Most Knockout of the Night Awards|| [[Anderson Silva]]||7 |- |Most Submission of the Night Awards|| [[Joe Lauzon]]||6 |- |Most Fight of the Night Awards|| [[Nate Diaz]]||8 |- |Most total fight time|| [[Frankie Edgar]]||6:02:51 |- |Most takedowns in a single bout|| [[Khabib Nurmagomedov]]||21 of 27 attempts |- |Fastest knockout|| [[Duane Ludwig]]||0:06 |- |Fastest submission|| [[Oleg Taktarov]]||0:09 |- |Fastest Title Fight Knockout|| [[Conor McGregor]]||0:13 |- |Fastest Title Fight Submission|| [[Ronda Rousey]]||0:14 |- |} ==UFC Hall of Fame== {{main|UFC Hall of Fame}} '''Mark Coleman''' (16-10-0) {| class="wikitable" !Age: |45 |- !Height: |6’1" ( 185 cm ) |- !Weight: |205 lbs ( 93 kg ) |- !Resides: |Columbus, Ohio |- | colspan="2" |LAST FIGHT UFC 109 Relentless |- | colspan="2" |Coleman, the first UFC Heavyweight Champion, is the “Godfather of Ground & Pound.” |} '''Randy Couture''' (18-10-0) {| class="wikitable" !Age: |47 |- !Height: |6’2" ( 188 cm ) |- !Weight: |205 lbs ( 93 kg ) |- !Resides: |Las Vegas, NV |- | colspan="2" |LAST FIGHT UFC 109 Relentless |- | colspan="2" |Couture is one of only five UFC Champions to hold belts in two weight classes. |} '''Pat Miletich''' (27-5-2) {| class="wikitable" |From: |Davenport, IA - USA USA |- |Age: |50 |- |Height: |5' 10" ( 177 cm ) |- |Weight: |180 lb ( 81 kg ) |} '''Royce Gracie''' (13-2-2) {| class="wikitable" !Age: |43 |- !Height: |6’1" ( 180 cm ) |- !Weight: |180 lbs ( 82 kg ) |- !Resides: |Rio de Janeiro, Brazil |- | colspan="2" |LAST FIGHT UFC 60 Hughes vs Gracie |- | colspan="2" |Gracie put Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu on the map in the United States with his amazing victory at UFC 1. |} '''Matt Hughes''' (45-7-0) {| class="wikitable" !Age: |36 |- !Height: |5’9" ( 175 cm ) |- !Weight: |170 lbs ( 77 kg ) |- !Resides: |Hillsboro, IL |- | colspan="2" |LAST FIGHT UFC 117 Silva vs Sonnen |- | colspan="2" |Hughes is one of the most dominant Welterweights in the UFC. |} '''Chuck Lidell''' (21-8-0) {| class="wikitable" !Age: |41 |- !Height: |6’2" ( 188 cm ) |- !Weight: |205 lbs ( 93 kg ) |- !Resides: |San Luis Obispo, CA |- | colspan="2" |LAST FIGHT UFC 115 Liddell vs Franklin |- | colspan="2" |Liddell has one of the longest running title reigns in UFC history. |} '''Forrest Griffin''' (19-7-0) {| class="wikitable" |From: |Columbus, Ohio USA |- |Fights Out Of: |Las Vegas, NV USA |- |Age: |39 |- |Height: |6' 3" ( 190 cm ) |- |Weight: |205 lb ( 93 kg ) |} '''Dan Severn''' (70-13-7) {| class="wikitable" !Age: |52 |- !Height: |6’2" ( 188 cm ) |- !Weight: |250 lbs ( 110 kg ) |- !Resides: |Coldwater, MI |- | colspan="2" |LAST FIGHT UFC 27 Ultimate Bad Boyz |- | colspan="2" |Severn was the first world-class wrestler to dominate the UFC. |} '''Ken Shamrock''' (26-11-2) {| class="wikitable" !Age: |46 |- !Height: |6’1" ( 185 cm ) |- !Weight: |205 lbs ( 93 kg ) |- !Resides: |San Diego, CA |- | colspan="2" |LAST FIGHT Ortiz vs. Shamrock 3 - The… |- | colspan="2" |Shamrock is known as one of the most successful early UFC fighters. |} '''Stephan Bonnar''' (17-8-0) {| class="wikitable" |From: |Munster, Indiana USA |- |Fights Out Of: |Las Vegas, Nevada USA |- |Age: |41 |- |Height: |6' 4" ( 193 cm ) |- |Weight: |205 lb ( 93 kg ) |- |Reach |80" |} '''Tito Ortiz''' 17-11-1 {| class="wikitable" !Age: |37 |- !Height: |6’3" ( 190 cm ) |- !Weight: |205 lbs ( 93 kg ) |- !Resides: |Huntington Beach, CA |- | colspan="2" |Ortiz currently holds 6 UFC light heavyweight title records. |} '''Charles Lewis''' {| class="wikitable" !'''Age:''' |47 |- !'''Resides:''' |San Bernadino, Ca |- | colspan="2" |As one of the three founders of the MMA clothing brand Tapout, Lewis (a.k.a. "Mask") was known as one of the biggest supporters and fans of MMA |} ==Media== ===Television=== *[[Fox UFC]] (until 2018) *[[UFC All Access]] *[[UFC Connected]] *[[UFC Primetime]] *[[UFC Tonight]] *[[UFC Ultimate Insider]] *[[UFC Unleashed]] *[[The Ultimate Fighter]] *[[Friends]] Season 3, Episode 24 "The One with the Ultimate Fighting Champion" is based around the UFC and features [[Jon Favreau]] as Pete Becker, Monica's millionaire boyfriend who seeks to become the "Ultimate Fighting Champion," losing his first fight due to his opponent "standing on [his] neck," and the second to a man who "Trains by traveling to Iran and pulling the arms off of thieves." In his third fight Pete loses to a fighter who "goes for his favorite area," causing Ross to note Pete can no longer have kids. ===Music=== *''UFC: Ultimate Beat Downs, Vol. 1'', an album of music featured in and inspired by the UFC. ===Video games=== *''[[Ultimate Fighting Championship (video game)|Ultimate Fighting Championship]]'' ([[Dreamcast]] and [[PlayStation]]) *''[[UFC: Tapout]]'' ([[Xbox (console)|Xbox]]) *''[[UFC: Throwdown]]'' ([[GameCube]], [[PlayStation 2]]) *''[[UFC: Tapout 2]]'' (Xbox) *''[[UFC: Sudden Impact]]'' (PlayStation 2) *''[[UFC 2009 Undisputed]]'' ([[PlayStation 3]] and [[Xbox 360]]) *''[[UFC Undisputed 2010]]'' ([[PlayStation Portable]], PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, [[iPod Touch]], [[iPad]], [[iPhone]]) *''[[UFC Personal Trainer]]'' (PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, [[Wii]]) *''[[UFC Undisputed 3]]'' (PlayStation 3, Xbox 360) *''[[EA Sports UFC]]'' (PlayStation 4, Xbox One) *''[[EA Sports UFC 2]]'' (PlayStation 4, Xbox One) *''[[EA Sports UFC 3]]'' (PlayStation 4, Xbox One) In January 2007, Zuffa and video game developer/publisher [[THQ]] announced a license agreement giving THQ worldwide rights to develop titles under the UFC brand. The agreement gives THQ exclusive rights to current and next-generation consoles as well as to PC and handheld titles. Also included are "certain wireless rights" which were not detailed. The licensing agreement was set to expire in 2011, although it appeared to have been extended to 2017. On June 6, 2012, during the E3 Exhibition, THQ had announced that they will be giving the license of UFC Undisputed to EA. ===Action figures=== ====Round 5==== The first UFC action figure collectibles were released by Round 5 Corporation in May 2008.[http://www.round5mma.com/index.php Round 5 – The Official UFC Collectible]. Round5mma.com. Retrieved on May 3, 2011. Series one of their figures includes [[Quinton Jackson|Quinton "Rampage" Jackson]], [[Matt Hughes (fighter)|Matt Hughes]], [[Tito Ortiz]], and [[Randy Couture]]. Series two (released on November 10, 2008) includes [[Wanderlei Silva]], [[Sean Sherk]], [[Rich Franklin]], and [[Anderson Silva]]. In July 2009, Round 5 acquired the UFC license through Jakks Pacific and subsequently released 5 more series under the UFC and Pride brands. 2 packs were released in August 2010 and includes a UFC Octagon cage and Pride ring display stand. Limited edition versions include fabric walk out tees or paint variations and are limited in number with foil and holographic packaging variances. Special edition and exclusive versions have been released at various UFC Fan Expo events. ====Jakks Pacific==== On June 10, 2008, it was announced that UFC had signed an exclusive four-year contract with [[Jakks Pacific]] to create action figures for UFC. {{As of|2009}} the schedule envisages the release of these figures in November 2009. They have currently been 8 series released and they feature special Legends, Pride, and WEC style figures as well. Three 2 packs series have also been released, as well as several expo and internet exclusives. There are also several different octagon cage playsets that have been released, including the "Octagon Playset", "Official Scale Octagon Playset", and "Electronic Reaction Octagon Playset". A Pridestyle ring playset was also originally planned; however, no news have been given on its status or release date since then.[http://www.ringsidecollectibles.com/Merchant2/merchant.mv?Screen=PROD&Store_Code=R&Product_Code=UFCR-002&Category_Code=UFCR] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425062717/http://www.ringsidecollectibles.com/Merchant2/merchant.mv?Screen=PROD&Store_Code=R&Product_Code=UFCR-002&Category_Code=UFCR|date=April 25, 2012}}{{cite news| title=Jakks UFC Octagon Official Scale Playset MMAFigs.com|url =http://www.mmafigs.com/index.php/mma_ufc_figure_newsline/3064-UFC-Octagon-Prototype-Preview-Videos.html|accessdate = June 21, 2009}}[http://www.ringsidecollectibles.com/Merchant2/merchant.mv?Screen=PROD&Store_Code=R&Product_Code=UFCR-004&Category_Code=UFCR] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121123151435/http://www.ringsidecollectibles.com/Merchant2/merchant.mv?Screen=PROD&Store_Code=R&Product_Code=UFCR-004&Category_Code=UFCR|date=November 23, 2012}} ;Jakks Pacific UFC Deluxe Figure Lineups: * Series 0: [[Royce Gracie]] (Legends Packaging), [[Brock Lesnar]], [[Frank Mir]], [[Rashad Evans]], [[Keith Jardine]], [[Houston Alexander]], [[Kendall Grove]], [[Miguel Torres (fighter)|Miguel Angel Torres]] (WEC Packaging){{cite news|title=UFC Series Zero Action Figure Prototype Images MMAFigs.com |url =http://www.mmafigs.com/index.php/mma_ufc_figure_newsline/3065-UFC-Series-Prototype-Figure-Videos-Brock-Lesnar-Royce-Gracie-More.html|accessdate = June 21, 2009}} * Series 1: [[Chuck Liddell]], [[Anderson Silva]], [[Forrest Griffin]], [[Michael Bisping]], [[Evan Tanner]] (Legends Packaging), [[Kevin Randleman]] (Pride Packaging), [[Cheick Kongo]], [[Mike Swick]]{{cite news| title=UFC Series 1 Action Figure Prototype Images MMAFigs.com| url =http://www.mmafigs.com/index.php/mma_ufc_figure_newsline/3049-UFC-Deluxe-Series-New-Jakks-Prototype-Images.html|accessdate = June 21, 2009}} * Series 2: [[Nate Marquardt]], [[Antônio Rodrigo Nogueira]], [[Mike Brown (fighter)|Mike Thomas Brown]] (WEC Packaging), [[Bas Rutten]] (unreleased in this series, moved to series 6), [[Georges St-Pierre]] (unreleased in this series, moved to series 6), [[Lyoto Machida]] (unreleased in this series, moved to series 5), [[Quinton Jackson]] (unreleased in this series, moved to series 8), [[Thiago Alves (fighter)|Thiago Alves]] (unreleased in this series, moved to series 6){{cite web |url=http://www.thefightnerd.com/ufc-deluxe-2-protos/ |title=UFC Deluxe series 2 prototype pics out! |publisher=The Fight Nerd |date=November 2, 2009 |accessdate=November 19, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904053855/http://www.thefightnerd.com/ufc-deluxe-2-protos/ |archive-date=September 4, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} * Series 3: [[Chuck Liddell]] (Legends Packaging), [[Karo Parisyan]], [[B.J. Penn]], [[Jon Fitch]], [[Mark Coleman]] (Legends Packaging), [[Thiago Silva (fighter)|Thiago Silva]], [[Maurício Rua]] (Pride Packaging) * Series 4: [[Wanderlei Silva]], [[Sean Sherk]], [[Rich Franklin]], [[Matt Hughes (fighter)|Matt Hughes]], [[Kimbo Slice]], [[Jamie Varner]] (WEC Packaging), [[Don Frye]] (Legends Packaging), [[Andrei Arlovski]] (unreleased in this series, later released in series 7) * Series 5: [[Lyoto Machida]] (1 of 100 inserts were also released randomly and contained a special die cast version of the UFC belt), [[Quinton Jackson]] (Pride Packaging), [[Matt Hamill]], [[Dan Severn]] (Legends), [[Kenny Florian]], [[Matt Serra]], [[Stephan Bonnar]] * Series 6: [[Thiago Alves (fighter)|Thiago Alves]], [[Randy Couture]] (unreleased, was originally supposed to be a 1 of 100 inserts that was to be released randomly and contain a special die cast version of the UFC belt), [[Georges St-Pierre]], [[Clay Guida]], [[Frank Mir]], [[Tito Ortiz]], [[Jens Pulver]] (WEC Packaging), [[Bas Rutten]] (Legends) * Series 7 (if bought at Target, each of them, except for Nogueira, also came with a replica UFC event mini-poster): [[B.J. Penn]] (Legends Packaging), [[Anderson Silva]], [[Andrei Arlovski]], [[Forrest Griffin]] (Legends Packaging), [[Diego Sanchez]], [[Antônio Rodrigo Nogueira]] (Pride Packaging, 1 of 100 inserts were also released randomly and contained a special die cast version of the Pride belt) * Series 8: [[Matt Hughes (fighter)|Matt Hughes]] (Legends Packaging), [[Chuck Liddell]] (Pride Packaging), [[Frankie Edgar]] (1 of 100 inserts were also released randomly and contained a special die cast version of the UFC belt), [[Nate Diaz]], [[Quinton Jackson]] ; Jakks Pacific UFC Deluxe 2 Packs Figures Lineups: * Series 1: Chuck Liddell vs. Wanderlei Silva, Frank Mir vs. Brock Lesnar, Anderson Silva vs. Rich Franklin * Series 2: Lyoto Machida vs. Shogun Rua, Georges St-Pierre vs. Matt Hughes, Randy Couture vs. Chuck Liddell (was supposed to be canceled due to copyright issues; however, 1,000 packs managed to make it to several K-Mart stores) * Series 3: Chuck Liddell vs. Tito Ortiz, B.J. Penn vs. Kenny Florian, Dan Severn vs. Royce Gracie (Legends Packaging) * Expos Exclusives: Georges St-Pierre (Boston Expo 2010, 1 of 500) * Ringside Collectibles Internet Exclusives: Forrest Griffin vs. Stephan Bonnar: The Ultimate Fighter Season 1 Final, Dana White, Quinton Rampage Jackson 1 of 1000{{cite web |url=http://www.ringsidecollectibles.com/Merchant2/merchant.mv?Screen=CTGY&Store_Code=R&Category_Code=UFC_MMA_EXCLUSIVES |title=WWE Toys, Wrestling Action Figures, Jakks Pacific, Classic Superstars Action F: UFC MMA Exclusives |publisher=Ringsidecollectibles.com |date= |accessdate=November 19, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121123151359/http://www.ringsidecollectibles.com/Merchant2/merchant.mv?Screen=CTGY&Store_Code=R&Category_Code=UFC_MMA_EXCLUSIVES |archive-date=November 23, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} ===DVD=== Every pay-per-view UFC event has been released onto DVD. ''UFC 23'' through ''UFC 29'' were not released in the US on home video or DVD by SEG. They have since been released onto boxsets which feature around 10 events each set, in chronological order. ===PlayStation Network and Xbox Live=== UFC on-demand content launched for Xbox 360 on December 20, 2011. Subscribers are able to view pay-per-view events in high definition, connect with friends to predict fight results, and have the ability to compare fighter statistics and records.{{cite web|url=http://majornelson.com/2011/10/07/ufc-on-xbox-live-launching-december-1st/ |title=Xbox Live's Major Nelson » UFC on Xbox LIVE launching December 1st : |publisher=Majornelson.com |date=October 7, 2011 |accessdate=November 19, 2012}} The [[UFC Fight Pass]] application was also planned for [[PlayStation 4]] in early 2015.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/ufcfightpass/status/546513103932772354|title=UFC Fight Pass on Twitter|work=Twitter}} ==UFC international broadcasters== The UFC's PPV events are broadcast live on PPV USA and BT Sport in the UK-Ireland until January 1, 2019 when [[Eleven Sports UK & Ireland|Eleven Sports]] take over the rights.{{Cite web|url=http://www.punditarena.com/mma/ckelleher/bt-sport-reportedly-lose-rights-ufc-early-december/|title=BT Sport Reportedly Lose Rights To UFC From Early December - Pundit Arena|website=www.punditarena.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-10-20}} In Latin America, events are broadcast live on [[Televisa|Fighting Sports Network]] in Pay TV (Cable and Satellite) of SKY Satellite. Free TV Channels in Mexico, [[Fox Sports (Latin America)|Fox Sports 2]] and [[Fox Premium]] in Pay TV (Cable and Satellite) South America and Central America are broadcast with tape-delay. In Brazil, events are broadcast live on Combate Channel from [[Globosat]]. [[Rede Globo]]'s are broadcast tape-delayed from 12:00 am. In Southeast Asia (exclude the Philippines), Hong Kong, and Papua New Guinea, UFC events are broadcast on [[Fox Movies Premium]] (2012-2013) {{Citation|last=FNGIndonesia|title=UFC on Fox Movies Premium|date=2012-02-16|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GpWVl3UGNYE|access-date=2018-09-22}} and [[Fox Sports Asia|Fox Sports]] {{Citation|last=UFCPromoChinese|title=UFC on Fox Sports Asia - THhe New Home of UFC|date=2013-08-08|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d5A59jaB1GA|access-date=2018-09-22}} (2013-now).{{Cite news|url=http://www.ufc.com/news/ufc-and-fox-sports-asia-announce-broadcast-partnership-renewal-061517|title=UFC and Fox Sports Asia announce broadcast partnership renewal|work=UFC|access-date=2018-09-22}} In [[India]], events are broadcast on [[Sony SIX|Sony Six]]. In the [[Philippines]], UFC was also aired on [[Balls (TV channel)|Balls]] (now [[ABS-CBN Sports and Action|ABS-CBN Sports + Action HD]]) from 2009 until 2015, since moved to [[Sports5]] (including [[TV5 (Philippines)|TV5]], [[AksyonTV]] and [[Hyper (TV channel)|Hyper]] on Channel 91 (SD) and 261 (HD) via [[Cignal]]) starting January 3, 2016.{{cite news|title=Cignal gets rights to air UFC fights live as Balls Channel announces it is going off the air|url=http://www.spin.ph/combat-sports/news/ufc-on-sports5-cignal-abs-cbn-balls-skycable-destiny-cable|accessdate=April 10, 2016|publisher=Spin.PH|date=December 21, 2015}}{{cite news|title=UFC, Cignal, TV5 seal broadcast deal|url=http://www.philstar.com/sports/2015/12/30/1537590/ufc-cignal-tv5-seal-broadcast-deal|accessdate=April 10, 2016|publisher=Spin.PH|date=December 30, 2015}} In Indonesia, UFC events are currently broadcast on [[TvOne (Indonesia)|tvOne]] starting January 15, 2018;{{Cite news|url=https://www.viva.co.id/sport/onepride/995811-3-duel-ufc-yang-disiarkan-tvone-senin-15-januari-2018|title=3 Duel UFC yang Disiarkan tvOne, Senin 15 Januari 2018 – Viva|date=2018-01-11|access-date=2018-09-22|language=id}} previously, this events was also broadcast on [[RCTI]] {{Citation|last=Official RCTI|title=UFC ( Ultimate Fighting Championship ) Mulai 7 Februari|date=2013-02-04|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yKuG0KPgwuA|access-date=2018-09-22}} and [[iNews]] {{Citation|last=Official iNewsTV Promo|title=SINDOTV - UFC Ultimate Fighting Champhionship|date=2015-02-12|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y5ZX90YUy8A|access-date=2018-09-22}} since 2012 until the end of 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://mmajunkie.com/2012/11/ufc-announces-partnership-with-mnc-media-in-indonesia-plans-future-events|title=UFC announces partnership with MNC Media in Indonesia, plans future events|date=2012-11-10|work=MMAjunkie|access-date=2018-09-22}} ==See also== {{portal|MMA}} *[[List of UFC champions]] *[[List of UFC events]] *[[List of current UFC fighters]] *[[List of UFC bonus award recipients]] *[[List of current mixed martial arts champions]] *[[UFC Fight Pass]] ==Notes== {{reflist|group=note}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.ufc.com|mobile=m.ufc.com}} *{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20010221231634/http://www.ufc.tv/Index1.htm |date=February 21, 2001 |title=Ultimate Fighting Championship }} {{MMA organizations}} {{UFC Championships}} {{UFC Hall of Fame}} {{UFC Events}} [[Category:Ultimate Fighting Championship| ]] [[Category:1993 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Mixed martial arts organizations]] [[Category:Ultimate Fighting Championship television series]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1993]] [[Category:Kohlberg Kravis Roberts companies]]

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:1973 photographs]] to [[Category:1973 works]] per [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 July 27]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{italic title|all=yes}} '''''Untitled (Rape Scene)''''' is a [[color photograph]] documentation{{cite news|url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/arts/art/reviews/9525/|title=Human Nature|date= July 26, 2004|publisher=''New York'' magazine|last=Stevens|first=Mark}} created from a 35mm slide by [[Cuban American]] artist [[Ana Mendieta]]. She made it during an April 1973 [[Performance art|performance]] while still a student at the [[University of Iowa]]. It is one of three photographs she created in reaction to the rape and murder of a woman on campus.{{cite news|url=http://www.brooklynrail.org/2004/09/art/ana-mendieta-earth-body-sculpture-and-pe|title=Ana Mendieta: Earth Body, Sculpture and Performance|work=The Brooklyn Rail|last=Heuer|first=Megan|date=September 1, 2004}} The [[Tate Gallery]] in London, which owns the work, describes it this way:
Mendieta invited her fellow students to her apartment where, through a door left purposefully ajar, they found her in the position recorded in this photograph, which recreated the scene as reported in the press. Some time later, Mendieta recalled that her audience "all sat down, and started talking about it. I didn’t move. I stayed in position about an hour. It really jolted them."''Ana Mendieta,'' p.127, note 11. In 1980, she commented that the rape had "moved and frightened" her, elaborating: "I think all my work has been like that – a personal response to a situation ... I can’t see being theoretical about an issue like that."''Ana Mendieta,'' p. 90. On another occasion she explained that she had created this work "as a reaction against the idea of violence against women."Viso 2004, p.256, note 58.{{cite web|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/mendieta-untitled-rape-scene-t13355/text-summary|title= Untitled (Rape Scene)|publisher=Tate Gallery}}
Art writer Megan Heuer describes the work as capturing the artist's interest in violence. Influenced by the work of the [[Viennese Actionism|Viennese Actionists]], ''Untitled (Rape Scene)'' also expresses Mendieta's desire to evoke a visceral reaction from her audience. ==Bibliography== *''Ana Mendieta,'' exhibition catalogue, Centro Galego de Arte Contemporánea, Santiago de Compostela, [[Kunsthalle Düsseldorf]] and [[Fundació Antoni Tàpies]], Barcelona, 1996. *Viso, Olga M. ''Ana Mendieta: Earth Body, Sculpture and Performance 1972–1985,'' exhibition catalogue, [[Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden]], [[Smithsonian Institution]], Washington DC, 2004. *Szymanek, Angelique. "Bloody Pleasures: Ana Mendieta's Violent Tableaux," ''Signs: Journal of Women in Culture and Society'' 41, no. 4 (Summer 2016): 895-925. ==References== {{reflist}} {{performance art}} Angelique Szymanek, "Bloody Pleasures: Ana Mendieta's Violent Tableaux," Signs: Journal of Women in Culture and Society 41, no. 4 (Summer 2016): 895-925. [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Performance art]] [[Category:1973 works]] [[Category:1973 in art]] [[Category:University of Iowa]] [[Category:Feminist art]] [[Category:Political art]] [[Category:Collection of the Tate galleries]] [[Category:Works about rape]] [[Category:1970s photographs]]

[[Brazil]] is the 13th largest video game market in the world as of 2017, and the largest in Latin America, with a revenue of 1,3 billion US dollars.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://newzoo.com/insights/infographics/the-brazilian-gamer-2017/|title=The Brazilian Gamer {{!}} 2017 {{!}} Newzoo|work=Newzoo|access-date=2017-07-17|language=en-US}}</ref> Video games were not permitted for import into Brazil until the 1990s, and were then heavily taxed as non-essential goods. As a result, a [[black market]] developed around [[Copyright infringement|pirating games]], driven by the lack of official channels for purchasing games. Many game companies avoided expansion into the country for these reasons until the 2010s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techinbrazil.com/the-market-for-video-games-in-brazil|title=The Market for Video Games in Brazil|first=Marcelo|last=Teixeira|date=2 October 2015|publisher=|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref> Blaming high tariffs, Nintendo officially left the market in 2015, but returned in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/1/10/7524759/nintendo-brazil-wii-u-3ds-tariffs-taxes|title=Nintendo ends console and game distribution in Brazil, citing high taxes|first=Owen S.|last=Good|date=10 January 2015|publisher=|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref> Sega once retained a strong foothold in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/brazil-is-a-video-game-alternate-universe-where-sega-beat-nintendo|title=Brazil Is An Alternate Video Game Universe Where Sega Beat Nintendo|date=27 July 2015|publisher=|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref> In a three-episode series named ''Red Bull Parallels'', Red Bull explored the country's relation with gaming.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.redbull.com/us/en/games/stories/1331829250246/the-history-of-video-games-in-brazil|title=Watch our video history of gaming in Brazil|first=Jon|last=Partridge|publisher=|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref>
==Censorship== Since January 2008, the marketing of ''[[Counter-Strike]]'' is prohibited in the Brazilian territory{{which|date=December 2017}} by judicial decision. The judge argues that Counter-Strike and ''[[EverQuest]]'' games subvert social order.<ref>[http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/folha/informatica/ult124u364924.shtml Folha Online - Informática - Justiça proíbe Counter Strike em todo Brasil; Procon tenta recolher jogos - 18/01/2008]. .folha.uol.com.br. Retrieved on 2011-05-07.</ref>
It has since been lifted, although EverQuest is still illegal in physical form in [[Minas Gerais]].
==Video game development== Video game development exists in Brazil since as early as 1983, when [[Renato Degiovani]] developed the first computer games in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] called "''Aventuras na Selva''" (later renamed ''Amazônia'') and "''Aeroporto 83''" (Airport 83) for a computer specialized magazine called "Micro Sistemas".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.techtudo.com.br/noticias/noticia/2014/04/conheca-renato-degiovani-o-pioneiro-na-industria-de-games-no-brasil.html|title=Conheça Renato Degiovani: o pioneiro na indústria de games no Brasil|work=TechTudo|access-date=2017-07-17|language=pt-BR}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gizmodo.uol.com.br/primeiro-desenvolvedor-brasileiro/|title=Entrevista: Renato Degiovani, o primeiro desenvolvedor brasileiro de jogos - Gizmodo Brasil|website=gizmodo.uol.com.br|language=pt|access-date=2017-07-17}}</ref> Several years have passed with little to no significant development until the [[2000s (decade)|2000s]], when several companies started creating [[Advertising in video games|advergames]] and/or [[Massively multiplayer online role-playing game|MMORPGs]], and universities started offering game development degrees. [[Hoplon Infotainment|Hoplon]] was one of the first to be successful in the industry with [[Taikodom]].
The 2010s have been marked by a growing number of studios getting bigger relevance with proprietary [[indie game]] titles. The [[BIG Festival]] (Brazilian Independent Games Festival) was conceived in 2012 and is held every year in [[São Paulo]], gathering game industry professionals from the country and abroad and promoting indie titles for the Brazilian market.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bigfestival.com.br|title=BIG Festival 2017 {{!}} Brazil's Independent Games Festival|website=bigfestival.com.br|language=pt-br|access-date=2017-07-17}}</ref>
The biggest game dev scenes are from [[São Paulo]], [[Porto Alegre]] and [[Brasília]].
=== Game developers from Brazil === {| class="wikitable" |- | '''Company''' | '''Location''' | '''Founded''' |- | [[Tectoy]] | [[Campinas]] | [[1987 in video gaming|1987]] |- | [[Continuum Entertainment]] | [[Curitiba]] | [[1998 in video gaming|1998]] |- | [[Hoplon Infotainment]] | [[Florianópolis]] | [[2000 in video gaming|2000]] |- | [[Chroma Squad|Behold Studios]] | [[Brasília]] |- | [[Swordtales]] | [[Porto Alegre]] |- | [[Aquiris]] | [[Porto Alegre]] |- | JoyMasher |- | [[Luderia]] |- | [[MTI Studios]] |- | [[Insolita]] | [[São Paulo]] |- | [[Duaik]] | [[São Paulo]] |- | [[Jynx Playware]] | [[Recife]] |- | [[Oktagon (video game developer)|Oktagon]] | [[Rio de Janeiro]] |}
==Media== '''Print Media''' * [[Electronic Gaming Monthly|EGM Brasil]], since 2002 * [[Nintendo World]], since 1998 * [[Official Xbox Magazine|Revista Xbox 360]], since 2008
==Brazilian video game rating== The [[Brazilian advisory rating system|ClassInd]] (advisory rating) is the institute responsible for the software given for review on Brazil.
==See also== * [[Latin American communities and video games]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.abragames.org/ ABRAGAMES site (Brazilian Association of Game Developers)] {{pt icon}} * [http://www.acigames.com.br/ ACIGAMES site (Commercial, Industrial and Cultural Gaming Association)] {{pt icon}}

{{italic title}} {{About|the media franchise}} {{Infobox media franchise |title = ''Westworld'' |image = Westworld Logo.jpg |imagesize = |caption = Original film logo |creator = [[Michael Crichton]] |origin = ''[[Westworld (film)|Westworld]]'' (1973) |films = * {{nowrap|''[[Westworld (film)|Westworld]]'' (1973)}} * {{nowrap|''[[Futureworld]]'' (1976)}} |tv = * {{nowrap|''[[Beyond Westworld]]'' (1980)}} * {{nowrap|''[[Westworld (TV series)|Westworld]]'' (2016–present)}} }} '''''Westworld''''' is an American [[science fiction]]-[[thriller (genre)|thriller]] [[media franchise]] which began in 1973 with the release of the film ''[[Westworld (film)|Westworld]]'', written and directed by [[Michael Crichton]]. The film depicts a technologically advanced, Western-themed amusement park populated by [[android (robot)|androids]] that malfunction and begin killing the human visitors; it was followed by the sequel film ''[[Futureworld]]'' (1976). In 1980, there was a short-lived television series, ''[[Beyond Westworld]]''. A television series called ''[[Westworld (TV series)|Westworld]]'', produced by [[HBO]] and based on the original film, debuted on October 2, 2016. A second season aired in April 2018, with a third season ordered the following month. ==Film series== ===Films=== ====''Westworld'' (1973)==== {{Main article|Westworld (film)}} ''Westworld'' was the first theatrical feature novelist [[Michael Crichton]] directed, after one TV movie.{{cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/thismonth/article.jsp?cid=12461&mainArticleId=245816 |title=Westworld |publisher=Tcm.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-29}} It was also the first feature film to use [[#Digital image processing|digital image processing]] to [[pixellate]] photography in order to simulate an android's point of view.[http://www.beanblossom.in.us/larryy/cgi.html A Brief, Early History of Computer Graphics in Film] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120717074134/http://www.beanblossom.in.us/larryy/cgi.html |date=2012-07-17 }}, [[Larry Yaeger]], 16 Aug 2002 (last update), retrieved 24 March 2010 The film was nominated for [[Hugo Award|Hugo]], [[Nebula Award|Nebula]] and [[Saturn Awards|Saturn]] awards. The film was well-received by critics.{{cite web |url=http://rottentomatoes.com/m/westworld/ |title=Westworld (1973) |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=October 10, 2016}} The story is about amusement park robots that malfunction and begin killing visitors. It stars [[Yul Brynner]] as an android in a futuristic Western-themed amusement park, and [[Richard Benjamin]] and [[James Brolin]] as guests of the park. ====''Futureworld'' (1976)==== {{Main article|Futureworld}} ''Futureworld'' is the [[sequel]] to the Michael Crichton film. The sequel stars [[Peter Fonda]], [[Blythe Danner]], [[Arthur Hill (actor)|Arthur Hill]], [[Stuart Margolin]], [[John P. Ryan (actor)|John Ryan]], and [[Yul Brynner]], who makes a [[cameo appearance]] in a [[dream sequence]]. Other than Brynner, none of the cast members from the original film appear, and original writer-director Crichton was not involved.Variety Staff. December 31, 1975. [http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117791173.html?categoryid=31&cs=1 "Futureworld"], ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''. The story is set two years after the Westworld tragedy, with the Delos corporation having reopened the park. The story starts when [[newspaper reporter]] Chuck Browning ([[Peter Fonda]]) and [[Broadcast journalism|TV reporter]] Tracy Ballard ([[Blythe Danner]]) are invited to review the park. ===Principal cast=== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; width:70%;" |- !rowspan="2" |Characters !colspan="2" |Film |- !style="text-align:center; width:50%;"|''[[Westworld (film)|Westworld]]''
(1973) !style="text-align:center; width:50%;"|''[[Futureworld]]''
(1976) |- !The Gunslinger |colspan="2"| [[Yul Brynner]] |- !Peter Martin |colspan="1"| [[Richard Benjamin]] |colspan="1" style="background:lightgrey;"| |- !John Blane |colspan="1"| [[James Brolin]] |colspan="1" style="background:lightgrey;"| |- !Chuck Browning |colspan="1" style="background:lightgrey;"| |colspan="1"| [[Peter Fonda]] |- !Tracy Ballard |colspan="1" style="background:lightgrey;"| |colspan="1"| [[Blythe Danner]] |- !Dr. Duffy |colspan="1" style="background:lightgrey;"| |colspan="1"| [[Arthur Hill (actor)|Arthur Hill]] |- !Dr. Schneider |colspan="1" style="background:lightgrey;"| |colspan="1"| [[John P. Ryan (actor)|John P. Ryan]] |- !Harry |colspan="1" style="background:lightgrey;"| |colspan="1" |[[Stuart Margolin]] |} ===Crew=== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; width:70%;" |- !rowspan="2" |Role !colspan="2" |Film |- !style="text-align:center; width:50%;"|''[[Westworld (film)|Westworld]]''
(1973) !style="text-align:center; width:50%;"|''[[Futureworld]]''
(1976) |- !Director | [[Michael Crichton]] | [[Richard T. Heffron]] |- !Producer | Paul N. Lazarus III | Paul N. Lazarus III and [[James T. Aubrey]] |- !Screenplay | [[Michael Crichton]] | [[Mayo Simon]] and [[George Schenck]] |- !Composer | colspan="2"| [[Fred Karlin]] |- !Editor | [[David Bretherton]] | James Mitchell |- !Cinematographer | [[Gene Polito]] | Howard Schwartz and [[Gene Polito]] |- !Running time | 88 minutes | 104 minutes |} ==Television series== ===''Beyond Westworld'' (1980)=== {{Main article|Beyond Westworld}} ''Beyond Westworld'' was created by [[Michael Crichton]] which served as a continuation of the two feature films.{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/tv/show/153782/Beyond-Westworld/overview|title=Beyond Westworld}} The series stars Jim McMullan as Security Chief John Moore of the Delos Corporation. The story revolved around Moore having to stop the evil scientist, Quaid, as he plans to use the Delos robots to try to take over the world.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Westworld-The-Complete-Series/20111|title=Beyond Westworld DVD news: Announcement for Beyond Westworld - The Complete Series - TVShowsOnDVD.com|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140801042226/http://tvshowsondvd.com/news/Westworld-The-Complete-Series/20111|archivedate=2014-08-01|df=}} It premiered on March 5, 1980 on the television network [[CBS]] in the United States. The show was nominated for two [[Primetime Emmy Award]]s for Outstanding Achievement in Makeup and Outstanding Art Direction For a Series. Only five episodes were produced, of which three aired before the series' cancellation. ===''Westworld'' (2016–present)=== {{Main article|Westworld (TV series)}} ''Westworld'' is an American science fiction-thriller television series created by husband-wife duo [[Jonathan Nolan]] and [[Lisa Joy]]. Nolan serves as executive producer along with Joy, [[J. J. Abrams]] and [[Bryan Burk]].{{Cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2013/08/31/hbo-westworld-pilot-jj-abrams-jonathan-nolan/|title=HBO Greenlights Sci-Fi Pilot Westworld From J.J. Abrams and Jonathan Nolan|publisher=TVLine|last=Gelman|first=Vlada|date=August 31, 2013|accessdate=October 10, 2016}} The series takes place in fictional Westworld, a technologically advanced, [[Western (genre)|Western]]-themed [[amusement park]] populated completely by synthetic androids dubbed "Hosts". Westworld caters to high-paying visitors dubbed "Newcomers" (also known as "Guests"), who can do whatever they wish within the park, without fear of retaliation from the Hosts. ''Westworld'' premiered on October 2, 2016 on the cable television channel [[HBO]] in the United States.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/westworld-premiere-date-divorce-insecure-hbo-1201827128/|title=‘Westworld,’ ‘Divorce,’ ‘Insecure’ Set HBO Premiere Dates|work=Variety|first=Laura|last=Prudom|date=July 30, 2016|accessdate=October 10, 2016}} The series has been well received.{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/westworld/s01/ |title=Westworld: Season 1 (2016) |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=September 26, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/westworld |title=Westworld: Season 1 |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=October 10, 2016}} The series has also attained strong [[Nielsen ratings]] for HBO, with the U.S. series premiere attracting 1.96 million viewers.{{cite web |title=TV Ratings: ‘Westworld’ Premiere Matches ‘True Detective’ Season 1 |url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/tv-ratings-westworld-premiere-matches-true-detective-season-1-1201876517/ |first=Daniel |last=Holloway |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=October 3, 2016 |accessdate=October 10, 2016}} ==Video game== A [[first-person shooter]] based on the film, titled ''Westworld 2000'', was released in 1996.{{cite magazine |title=Westworld 2000 |magazine=[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]|issue=27|publisher=[[Imagine Media]] |date=March 1997 |page=98}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Westworld}} {{Michael Crichton}} [[Category:Westworld| ]] [[Category:Amusement parks in fiction]] [[Category:Film series]] [[Category:Films adapted into television programs]] [[Category:Films set in amusement parks]] [[Category:Films set in the future]] [[Category:Media franchises]] [[Category:Science fiction films by series]] [[Category:Science fiction Westerns]] [[Category:Cloning in fiction]] [[Category:Techno-thriller films]] [[Category:Warner Bros. franchises]]

revision.text:
[[File:Emo Chic.jpg|thumb|Example of a participant in [[emo]] subculture]] A '''youth subculture''' is a [[youth]]-based [[subculture]] with distinct styles, behaviors, and interests. Youth subcultures offer participants an identity outside of that ascribed by [[social institution]]s such as [[family]], [[employment|work]], [[home]] and [[school]]. Youth subcultures that show a systematic hostility to the dominant culture are sometimes described as [[counterculture]]s.
Youth [[music genre]]s are associated with many youth subcultures, such as [[hip hop culture|hip hop]], [[Punk subculture|punks]], [[emos]], [[rave]]rs, [[Juggalo]]s, [[Heavy metal subculture|metalheads]] and [[Goth subculture|goths]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.tn/books?id=SAGCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA22&lpg=PA22&dq=Youth+subcultures+that+stems+from+music&source=bl&ots=uYggnqXWuD&sig=HaTfGytpEY_7IqwcKetExcsg32c&hl=fr&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiUhdWw9pXWAhVm44MKHatDA5UQ6AEIaDAJ#v=onepage&q=Youth%20subcultures%20that%20stems%20from%20music&f=false|title=Beyond Subculture: Pop, Youth and Identity in a Postcolonial World|last=Huq|first=Rupa|date=2007-01-24|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781134470655|language=en}}</ref> The study of subcultures often consists of the study of the [[symbol]]ism attached to clothing, music, other visible affections by members of the subculture, and also the ways in which these same symbols are interpreted by members of the dominant culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mheducation.co.uk/openup/chapters/0335202500.pdf|title=CULTURES OF POPULAR MUSIC|last=Bennett|first=Andy|date=2001|website=www.mheducation.co.uk/|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
[[Socioeconomic class]], [[gender]], [[intelligence]], [[conformity]], [[morality]], and [[ethnicity]] can be important in relation to youth subcultures. Youth subcultures can be defined as meaning systems, modes of expression or [[lifestyle (sociology)|lifestyle]]s developed by groups in [[subordinate]] structural positions in response to dominant systems — and which reflect their attempt to solve structural contradictions rising from the wider societal context.<ref>Brake, Michael (1985) ''Comparative Youth Culture: The sociology of youth culture and youth subcultures in America, Britain and Canada'', Routledge, New York</ref>
The term ''scene'' can refer to an exclusive subculture or faction. Scenes are distinguished from the broad culture through either [[fashion]]; identification with specific (sometimes obscure or experimental) [[musical genre]]s or political perspectives; and a strong in-group or [[tribe|tribal]] mentality.<ref>Straw, Will (1991). "Systems of Articulation, Logics of Change: Communities and Scenes in Popular Music", ''Cultural Studies'', 5, 3, pp. 273, 368-88</ref> The term can be used to describe geographic subsets of a subculture, such as the Detroit [[drum and bass]] scene or the London goth scene.
==Theories about youth subculture== Early studies in [[youth culture]] were mainly produced by [[Functionalism (sociology)|functionalist sociologists]], and focus on youth as a single form of culture. In explaining the development of the culture, they utilized the concept of ''[[anomie]]''. [[Talcott Parsons]] argued that as we move from the family and corresponding values to another sphere with differing values, (e.g. the workplace) we would experience an "anomie situation."{{Fact|date=February 2007}} The generalizations involved in this theory ignore the existence of subcultures.
[[Marxist theory|Marxist theories]] account for some diversity, because they focus on classes and class-fractions rather than youth as a whole. Stuart Hall and Tony Jefferson described youth subcultures as symbolic or ritualistic attempts to resist the power of bourgeois hegemony by consciously adopting behavior that appears threatening to the establishment.<ref>Hall, Stuart & Jefferson, Tony. ''Resistance Through Rituals: Youth Subcultures in Post-war Britain'', Routledge, London. 1993</ref> Conversely, Marxists of the [[Frankfurt School]] of social studies argue that youth culture is inherently consumerist and integral to the divide-and-rule strategy of capitalism.{{Fact|date=April 2008}} They argue that it creates generation gaps and pits groups of youths against each other (e.g. [[mods and rockers]]), especially as youth culture is the dominant culture in the west.
[[Symbolic interactionism|Interactionist theorist]] Stan Cohen argues youth subcultures are not coherent social groupings that arise spontaneously as a reaction to social forces, but that mass media labeling results in the creation of youth subcultures by imposing an ideological framework in which people can locate their behavior.<ref>Cohen, Stan. ''Folk Devils and Moral Panics'', Paladin, London. 1964</ref> [[Post-structuralism|Post-structuralist theories]] of subculture utilize many of the ideas from these other theories, including hegemony and the role of the media. In his book, ''[[Subculture: The Meaning of Style]]'', [[Dick Hebdige]] describes subcultures as a reaction of subordinated groups that challenge the hegemony of the dominant culture.<ref>Hebdige, Dick. ''Subculture: The meaning of style'', Menthuen & Co, London. 1979</ref> This theory accounts for factors such as gender, ethnicity and age. Youth can be seen as a subordinate group in relation to the dominant, adult society.
Historical theorist Steven Mintz claims that until about 1955, youth subculture as such did not exist. Children aspired to (or were pulled into) adulthood as fast as their physical development allowed.<ref>Mintz, Steven. ''[[Huck's Raft: A History of American Childhood]]'', 2006, {{ISBN|0-674-01998-9}}</ref> Marcel Danesi argues that since then, the media, advertisers and others have made youth the dominant culture of Western societies, to the point that many people retain what others consider to be immature attitudes far into adulthood.<ref>Danesi, Marcel. ''Forever Young: The 'Teen-Aging' of Modern Culture'', 2003, {{ISBN|0-8020-8851-1}}</ref> This is further supported by P. Lewis, who claims that youth culture did not originate until the 1950s, with the development of [[rock and roll]].<ref>Lewis, P. ''The Fifties'', Heinemann, London. 1978</ref> However, other historians have claimed that youth culture may have developed earlier, particularly in the inter-war period.<ref>Fowler, D. ''The First Teenagers: The lifestyle of Young Wage Earners in Interwar Britain'', The Woburn Press, London. 1995</ref> There were examples of new youth subcultures emerging throughout that period, such as the [[flapper]].
Subcultures may also be seen as extensions of [[crowds (adolescence)|crowds]], subcultures that emerge within a specific school. Certain crowds (jocks, geeks, preppies, druggies, emos) are found in many, even most, high schools across the United States, though the particular terms used by the [[adolescence|adolescents]] in them may vary (nerds instead of geeks, etc.). Most of these can be found in other western countries as well, with the exception of [[jock (athlete)|jocks]]. (The United States is unusual in having athletics specifically affiliated with schools, although similar athletic affiliation groups exist in British [[public school (United Kingdom)|public school]]s.) <ref>Arnett, J. J. (2002). Adolescents in Western countries on the threshold of the 21st century. In B. Brown, R. Larson, & T. Saraswathi (Eds.), ‘’The world’s youth: Adolescence in eight regions of the globe.’’ New York: Cambridge University Press.</ref><ref>Delsing, M. J. M. H., ter Bogt, Tom F. M., Engles, R. C. M. E., & Meeus, W. H. J. (2007). Adolescents’ peer crowd identification in the Netherlands: Structure and associations with problem behaviors. ‘’Journal of Research on Adolescence, 17,’’ 467-480.</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Sociology}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[After-Eighty generation]] *[[Baby Boom Generation]] *[[Beat Generation]] *[[Counterculture of the 1960s]] *[[Hungry Generation]] *[[Generation X]] *[[Generation Y]] *[[Generation Z]] *[[La Sape]] *[[List of subcultures]] *[[Street fashion]] *[[Trash culture]] *[[Youth voice]] {{div col end}}
